text: Well, there's ways to approach adding new variables that explicitly orthogonalize off of existing variables. Certainly one of the approaches that we take, and this is an approach that is taken in a variety of off-the-shelf machine learning methods, is residualization. So you learn a model based on one feature, and then you go back to all the other features and you learn the model that best explains the residual returns that are not already explained by the feature that you had previously modeled. Let's say that you've got the highest conviction in time series. You go through your time series features, you generate the models, you get the residual returns, and then you go to your next set of features. Let's say it's term structure, and you allow your term structure models to learn off the returns that the time series models have. And then you, for the next set of features, maybe it's seasonality, you allow the seasonality models to learn off the returns that have not already explained by the time series models and the futures term structure models. And there's absolutely merit in this type of learning. And it's great because you can start with different variables first. You'll get slightly different models when you start with trending and residualize versus when you start with seasonality and residualize down. And I think it is worthwhile. model, seeking to add explanatory variables based on how well they explain residual returns rather than how well they explain the raw returns. Because so much of the explanatory power of any individual variable or many individual variables are conflated with the explanatory power of other variables. And often they're conflated with the explanatory power of the variables that everybody already knows about. So that idea of searching for new explanatory variables based on residualization makes a lot of sense to me. All I would say is that the process of determining, for example, we observe all the time taking literally random features, take a thousand features that are random signals, you're going to get some subset of them that will exhibit a sharp ratio over 10 years in excess of four. You absolutely will. And then when you apply them, you'll build a model and you'll apply them out of a sample and they'll have absolutely zero explanatory power. There's different types of meta features that you can use besides just the in-sample performance to determine if a model or a feature does have legitimate explanatory power, or it may be complimentary to the set of other features that you're using that I won't go into. Even taking a Pareto frontier of the best meta features, the explanatory power is extremely low. And so that process of adding a set of parameters to the model is extremely important. You're not adding new features to the data that you don't already have reasonably strong priors to. Now you're in a situation where you're adding noise and extra training. You're not adding extra training in a linear fashion because of the process. I mean, if you add random features together, you're only adding noise at a square root of the number of new random features that you're adding because of diversification. But you're still devoting risk budget to features that you have lower conviction. And so you're adding a set of parameters that you're adding noise and extra training. And so you're adding noise at a square root of the number of new random features that you're adding. Regardless of what you observe in there in sample performance, you need to proceed in that direction with more extreme caution.
